message.content:
cs.CR, cs.IT, cs.CC, cs.CY, cs.HC. 

The paper deals with authentication protocols and cryptography, which are typically studied in the cs.CR (Cryptography and Security) sub-category. The use of a semi-trusted computer and the focus on designing protocols that can be executed by humans suggest that the paper may also be relevant to the cs.HC (Human-Computer Interaction) sub-category. The paper also involves the use of functions that are easy for humans to evaluate, which could fall under the cs.IT (Information Theory) sub-category. The application of the hypercontractivity theorem and the analysis of statistical dimension suggest that the paper may also be relevant to the cs.CC (Computational Complexity) sub-category. Finally, the use of password functions and the focus on maintaining security guarantees suggest that the paper may also be relevant to the cs.CY (Cryptography and Security) sub-category.
